title: Are you a foodie?
intro: More and more people in the UK are describing themselves as 'foodies', but do they really know that much about the things they eat? In this programme we hear from one of Britain's top chefs and learn some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: In 2016, which is the most recent year we have statistics for, how many restaurants and mobile food services were there in the UK? was it: a) about 75,000, b) about 83,000 c) about 93,000
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: someone who is very interested in all aspects of food
something we have enough money to buy
the possibility of something bad happening

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I'm Rob.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now Rob, you look like you enjoy a good meal.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Ha. Well, I do like eating out and I like to think I know a good meal when I have one.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well that should give you an advantage with today’s quiz. In 2016, which is the last year we have statistics for, how many restaurants and mobile food services were there in the UK? Was it: a) about 75,000, b) about 83,000, or c) about 93,000?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, I know there are a lot, so I’m going to say 93,000 – but that is just a guess.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I’ll reveal the answer a little later in the programme. Today we’re talking about being a foodie. Rob, what is a foodie?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well I would describe a foodie as someone who has a strong interest in food. They like preparing it as well as eating it – they like using good ingredients and they’re probably not fans of fast food.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Angela Hartnett is one of Britain’s top chefs. In the BBC podcast The Bottom Line she talked about this topic. In this first clip how does she describe people who say they are foodies?

transcript.author: Angela Hartnett
transcript.text: I think people who say they are foodies buy the books, watch TV and will cook a little bit.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: She is saying that people who say they are foodies may not actually know that much about food. They buy books and watch cookery programmes on TV and will cook a little bit.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A little bit is a common phrase that means ‘a small amount’ and if you do something a little bit it means you don’t do it a lot. You could just say ‘a little’, but adding ‘bit’ to the phrase makes it very natural.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, we heard a little bit of Angela Hartnett there. Let’s hear more now. What’s her description of a foodie?

transcript.author: Angela Hartnett
transcript.text: My idea of a foodie is the very European idea that people go and shop every day, they understand one end of a pig from another. And maybe that's a bit romantic but I look at my mother, I look at my grandmother and our background, you know. They made food, they knew about what was expensive, they knew about quality and stuff like that.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Rob, do you know one end of a pig from another?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I hope so, but the point Angela Hartnett is making is that a true foodie has a good understanding, for example, of the different parts of an animal that are used in cooking and what they are used for. She says that idea might be a bit romantic.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We normally think of the word romantic when we are talking about love and relationships, but that’s not what it means here, is it?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: No. Romantic can also describe a pleasant ideal - an imaginary perfect way of life that forgets about the difficult things of everyday life.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Less hear some more from chef Angela Hartnett now. What is she worried about?

transcript.author: Angela Hartnett
transcript.text: I think we think we're foodies but I think food is expensive in this country. I don't think it's affordable for lots of people and I think we are in danger of not knowing, you know, how to cook any more, how to make a meal for a family of four for five pounds.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So Rob, what is Angela Hartnett worried about?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: She commented that food was very expensive here in Britain. Many people don’t have enough money to buy it, as she said it’s not affordable. She thinks we might be in danger of not being able to feed out families cheaply.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Can you say a bit more about the phrase in danger of?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Sure, the phrase to be in danger of is followed by a gerund and it means that there is the possibility of something bad happening. It’s not happened yet, but it could happen.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Thanks Rob. Right, well we’re in danger of running out of time so let’s get to the answer to the question I asked at the start of the programme. I asked how many restaurants or mobile food services there were in the UK in 2016.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I said – it was a guess – 93,000. But was I right?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I'm afraid you're 10,000 out! The answer is approximately 83,000.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Right, well I’ve still got a few more to get to before I can tick them all off my list!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Me too! Well, before we go, let’s recap the words and phrases we talked about today. The first was foodie.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, foodie is a modern word to describe someone who is very interested in all aspects of food, from buying, preparing and cooking to eating.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And someone who may or may not know which end of a pig is which!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I think you’re being a little bit silly there, aren’t you?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well a little bit was our next phrase, wasn’t it?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, a little bit: a very simple but a very natural conversational phrase that means a small amount.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The next word was the adjective romantic. Not used in the context of love here though was it?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: No, it wasn't. A romantic idea here is one that is not realistic but is an imagined perfect situation. For example, we have a very romantic view of our childhoods when every Christmas was a white Christmas and every summer holiday was baking hot and spent on the beach. Of course, it wasn’t like that at all. In reality both Christmas and summer were cold and rainy.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Then we had the adjective affordable, for something we have enough money to buy. Finally the phrase to be in danger of.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, for the possibility of something bad happening.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's it for this programme. For more, you can find us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and our YouTube pages, and of course our website bbclearningenglish.com where you can find all kinds of videos and audio programmes and activities to help you improve your English. Thanks for joining us and bye!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Bye-bye!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well I have to say, I’m a little bit hungry and if I don’t get some food soon I’m in danger of getting very grumpy.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: You're always grumpy, Neil. But there is a very affordable café around the corner, let’s head over there now, shall we?
